column2: German: Züllichau) is a town located within the Zielona Góra County
column4: western Poland. It is the administrative seat of the Gmina Sulechów. Established in the Middle Ages
column5: the town features many historical monuments significant to the Polish Lubusz Voivodeship (since the Local Government Reorganization Act of 1998). From 1975–1998 Sulechów was part of Zielona Góra Voivodeship. The town limits cover 6.88 square kilometres (2.66 sq mi). Olga Tokarczuk
column6: the Nobel Prize in Literature winner for 2018 was born in 1962 in Sulechów.

column1: Sulechów is situated in the historic Lower Silesia region
column2: north of the Oder river. The town centre is located about 22 km (14 mi) northeast of the regional capital Zielona Góra
column3: where the national road 32 to Poznań crosses the expressway S3 to Gorzów Wielkopolski. The regional Zielona Góra Airport is about 14 km (8.7 mi) away.

column1: The settlement of the region on the Middle Oder dates back to the 4th century AD.
By conquest at the end of the 10th century the area became part of the Polish realm of the Piast dynasty. It became part of the Duchy of Silesia
column5: later belonged to the Silesian Duchy of Głogów
column6: established in 1249-51 under the rule of Duke Konrad I.

column1: The settlement itself was first mentioned in a 1319 deed
column2: at the time when the warlike Ascanian margrave Waldemar of Brandenburg campaigned the area
column3: occupying Sulechów and neighbouring Świebodzin. Margrave Waldemar
column6: and the localities fell back to the Piast dukes of Głogów.When the last Piast duke Henry XI of Głogów died without issue in 1476
column7: inheritance claims were raised by his widow Barbara of Brandenburg and her father
column8: the Hohenzollern elector Albrecht Achilles. The Brandenburg influence met with fierce opposition by Henry's Piast cousin
column9: Duke Jan II the Mad of Żagań
column10: who nevertheless after several years of fighting had to sign an agreement
column11: whereby the Silesian towns of Crossen (Krosno) and the town passed to the Margraviate of Brandenburg as a fief of the Bohemian (Czech) Kingdom.

column4: was incorporated into the Brandenburg Neumark district by 1535
column5: ruled by Margrave John of Brandenburg-Küstrin who implemented the Protestant Reformation. Two years later
column6: the Piast duke Joachim of Münsterberg-Oels and his younger brothers officially waived any rights to the Crossen and Züllichau territories. Part of Brandenburg-Prussia from 1618
column7: the town was devastated during the Thirty Years' War but again flourished under the rule of the "Great Elector" Frederick William. From the 17th century
column8: clothmaking developed.Züllichau was part of the newly established Kingdom of Prussia since 1701. It became a garrison town of the Prussian Army. The Polish minority resisted Germanisation attempts
column9: carried out by the Prussian authorities. From 1815 it belonged to the Province of Brandenburg and became the administrative seat of the Züllichau-Schwiebus rural district within the Frankfurt Region. In 1828
column10: 18-year-old Frédéric Chopin visited the town and gave an improvised concert. Between 1871 and 1945 Züllichau was part of the German Reich.

column1: During World War II the Germans established two forced labour camps in the town
column2: mainly for the Soviets. The territory was conquered by Red Army forces during the Vistula-Oder Offensive in the final stage of World War II. In accordance with the Potsdam Agreement
column3: the town was incorporated into the Republic of Poland by the implementation of the Oder–Neisse line in 1945
column4: while the remaining German population was expelled. The historic Polish name Sulechów was restored.
